Plugins

Each feature of the calculator is implemented as a plugin containing methods that subclasses can override.

class symcalc.CalculatorPlugin(name, priority)

Plugins for the Calculator

Initializes the plugin

Parameters

  • name (str) – The name of the plugin

  • priority (int) – The priority of the plugin. Lower numbers designate that a plugin should be run before others

hook(calc)

Called by the calculator when the plugin is added

Parameters

calc (Calculator) – The calculator for which this plugin was registered

Return type

None

begin_interaction(command)

The beginning of a calculator interaction. The command may be complete, incomplete, or a multiline statement. No guarantees are made about the command. The object can be modified in place. The command may or may not be modified, split, or aborted before being parsed, handled, or executed.

commandCalculatorCommand

The command that begins the interaction

Parameters

command (CalculatorCommand) –

Return type

None

parse_command(command)

A command to be parsed by the plugin, meant to be overriden by subclasses. The given command may or may not be valid Python syntax, and the object can be modified in place.

The given command may have mutliple statements, such as 1+2;3+4

Parameters

command (CalculatorCommand) – The command to be parsed

Return type

None

handle_command(command)

A command to be handled by the plugin, meant to be overriden by subclasses. The given command is guaranteed to be valid Python syntax, and the object can be modified in place.

Parameters

command (CalculatorCommand) – The command to be parsed

Return type

None

handle_syntax_error_obj(command, exc)

The syntax error to be handled by the plugin, meant to be overriden by subclasses. The given command is guaranteed to be invalid Python syntax, and the object can be modified in place.

The given command may have mutliple statements, such as 1+2;3+4

Parameters

  • command (CalculatorCommand) – The command which caused the syntax error

  • exc (SyntaxError) – The resulting syntax error

Return type

None

handle_syntax_error(command, data)

The syntax error stderr output to be handled by the plugin, meant to be overriden by subclasses. The given command is guaranteed to be invalid Python syntax, and the object can be modified in place.

The given command may have mutliple statements, such as 1+2;3+4

Parameters

  • command (CalculatorCommand) – The command which caused the syntax error

  • exc (SyntaxError) – The stderr output from the resulting syntax error

  • data (str) –

Return type

None

handle_runtime_error(command, data)

The stderr output to be handled by the plugin, meant to be overriden by subclasses. The given command is guaranteed to be valid Python syntax, and the object can be modified in place.

Parameters

  • command (CalculatorCommand) – The command which caused the runtime error

  • data (str) – The stderr data

Return type

None

handle_resend(command)

Proxies a command to be resent to the calculator. This occurs after a runtime or syntax error. No guarantees are made about the validity of the syntax, and the given command can be modified in place

Parameters

command (CalculatorCommand) –

Return type

None

command_success(command)

Notifies the plugin after a successful command.

Note

The Calculator will not respect CalculatorCommand.abort, or CalculatorCommand.resend_command after the plugins are notified.

Parameters

command (CalculatorCommand) – The command that was executed

Return type

None

command_fail(command)

Notifies the plugin after a failed command. This could be due to SIGINT, an uncaught error, or other failing conditions

Parameters

command (CalculatorCommand) – The command that was executed

Return type

None

end_interaction(command)

The end of a calculator interaction. The command given is the fully parsed command, which is valid Python syntax but may not be the raw statement that was executed.

Parameters

command (CalculatorCommand) – The command that began the interaction

Return type

None

register_toggle(calc, toggle_name, setting_name, default)

Called by the plugin to register a toggle for the plugin with the Calculator. Should be used with CalculatorPlugin.if_enabled. Should not be overridden by plugins

Parameters

  • calc (Calculator) – The calculator to register the toggle

  • toggle_name (str) – The name of the directive to register. Cannot be None

  • setting_name (str) – The name of the setting in the calculator to hold the toggle. Cannot be None

  • default (bool) –

Raises

ValueError – If the toggle has already been registered or if toggle_name or setting_name is None

Return type

None

register_raw_toggle(calc, toggle_name, setting_name, default)

Called by the plugin to register a raw toggle for the plugin with the Calculator. Should not be overridden by plugins

Parameters

  • calc (Calculator) – The calculator to register the toggle

  • toggle_name (str) – The name of the directive to register. Cannot be None

  • setting_name (str) – The name of the setting in the calculator to hold the toggle. Cannot be None

  • default (bool) –

Raises

ValueError – If the toggle has already been registered or if toggle_name or setting_name is None

Return type

None

if_enabled()

A decorator to ensure that a function is only called when the plugin is enabled. Must have called CalculatorPlugin.register_toggle() first

if_external_enabled()

A decorator factory to ensure that a function is only called when some external setting is enabled
